Authors: Istiana Prihatini, Morag Glen, Caroline Mohammed
Title:
DIVERSITY OF FUNGI ASSOCIATED WITH NEEDLES OF PINUS RADIATA
IN TASMANIA
Keywords:
endophyte, needle fungi, Tasmania, fungal isolation,
environmental PCR, phylogenetic
Abstract:
Needle fungi have been extensively studied in conifers but
rarely in Pinus radiata. Previous studies in P. radiata have been mainly
based on fungal isolation. This study aimed to identify as many fungal
species as possible that were associated with P. radiata needles in
Tasmanian plantations by a direct PCR approach, using a reference
collection of isolates from Tasmania, mainland Australia and New
Zealand. Dothideomycetes was the most diverse group detected in this
study, with many OTUs infrequently detected by direct PCR and not
isolated. Leotiomycetes was the second most diverse order and
Sordariomycetes third, with many OTUs being frequently isolated but
rarely or not at all detected by direct PCR. DNA sequence data
facilitated the discrimination and identification of OTUs, but some
effort was required to eliminate sequences from poorly identified
isolates in public DNA databases.
